sentences.sentence: It was a quarter past nine when I started from home and walked across the Park, and then along Oxford Street to Baker Street( 贝克街，地名 ).
Two cabs were standing at the door, and as I entered I heard the sound of voices from above.
On entering his room I found Holmes in lively conversation with two men,
one of whom I recognized as Peter Jones, the official police detective,
while the other was a long, thin, sad-faced man, with a shiny hat and a long, very respectable coat.
“Ha! Our party is complete,” said Holmes, buttoning up( 扣上扣子 ) his jacket and taking his heavy hunting whip( 猎鞭 ).
“Watson, I think you know Mr( 先生 ). Jones, of Scotland Yard?
Let me introduce you to Mr( 先生 ). Merryweather, who is to be our companion in tonight’s adventure.”
“We’re hunting in couples again, Doctor, you see,” said Jones.
“Our friend here is a wonderful man for starting a chase( 追捕 ).
All he wants is an old dog to help him to do the running down.”
“I hope a wild goose may not prove to be the end of our chase( 追捕 ),” said Mr( 先生 ). Merryweather gloomily( 悲观地 ).
“You may trust Mr( 先生 ). Holmes, sir,” said the detective.
“He has his own methods, which are,
if he won’t mind my saying so, just a little too theoretical and fantastic,
but he has the makings of( 具有成为...的素质 ) a detective in him.
Once or twice, as in that business of the Sholto murder and the Agra treasure, he has been more nearly correct than the official force.”
“Oh, if you say so, Mr( 先生 ). Jones, it is all right,” said the stranger.
“Still, I confess( 坦白 ) that I miss my game of cards.
It is the first Saturday night for twenty-seven years that I have had to miss it.”
“I think you will find,” said Sherlock Holmes,
“that you will play for a higher stake( 赌注 ) tonight than you have ever done yet,
and that the play will be more exciting.
For you, Mr( 先生 ). Merryweather, the stake( 赌注 ) will be some 30,000 pounds;
and for you, Jones, it will be the man upon whom you wish to lay your hands.”
“John Clay, the murderer, thief, smasher, and forger( 伪造者 ),” said Mr( 先生 ). Jones.
“He’s a young man, Mr( 先生 ). Merryweather, but he is at the head of his profession,
and I would rather capture( 捕获 ) him than any criminal in London.
Young John Clay is a remarkable man.
His grandfather was a duke( 公爵 ), and he himself has been to Eton and Oxford.
His brain is as cunning( 灵活的 ) as his fingers,
and though we meet signs of him at every turn( 总是，处处 ), we never know where to find the man himself.
He’ll rob a house in Scotland one week, and be raising money to build an orphanage( 孤儿院 ) in Cornwall the next.
I’ve been after him for years and have never set eyes on him yet.”
“I hope that I may have the pleasure of introducing you tonight,” said Holmes.
“I’ve had one or two little turns also with Mr( 先生 ). John Clay, and I agree with you that he is at the head of his profession.
It is past ten, however, and quite time that we started.
If you two will take the first cab, Watson and I will follow in the second.”
Sherlock Holmes was not very talkative during the long drive,
and lay back in the cab humming( 哼唱 ) the tunes which he had heard in the afternoon.
We passed through a maze( 迷宫 ) of gas-lit streets until we came to Farrington Street.
“We are close now,” said my friend.
“This fellow Merryweather is a bank director, and personally concerned in the matter.
I thought it best to have Jones with us also.
He is not a bad fellow, though an absolute idiot in his profession.
He has one positive virtue.
He is as brave as a bulldog( 斗牛犬 ) and holds on as tightly as a lobster( 龙虾 ) if he gets his claws upon anyone.
Here we are, and they are waiting for us.”
We had reached the same busy road where we had found ourselves in the morning.
Our cabs were dismissed,
and, following Mr( 先生 ). Merryweather, we passed down a narrow passage and through a side door, which he opened for us.
Within there was a small passage, which ended in a heavy iron gate.
Mr( 先生 ). Merryweather opened the gate, and led us down some stone steps, which ended at another heavy, solid gate.
Mr( 先生 ). Merryweather stopped to light a lantern,
and then led us down a dark passage that smelt of earth,
and then, after opening a third door, into a cellar full of large, heavy boxes.
“You are quite safe from above,” Holmes remarked as he held up the lantern and looked about him.
“And from below,” said Mr( 先生 ). Merryweather, striking his stick upon the stone tiles( 地砖 ) which lined the floor.
“Why, dear me, it sounds quite hollow( （声音）空洞的 )!” he remarked, looking up in surprise.
“Quiet, please!” said Holmes severely.
“You have already endangered the whole success of our expedition( 探险 ).
Please sit down on one of those boxes, and do not interfere( 妨碍 )!”
The solemn( 表情严肃的 ) Mr( 先生 ). Merryweather sat on the edge of a crate( 大木箱 ),
with a very injured expression upon his face,
while Holmes fell upon his knees upon the floor
and, with the lantern and a magnifying lens( 放大镜 ), began to closely examine the cracks( 裂缝 ) between the stones.
A few seconds were enough to satisfy him, for he sprang to his feet again and put his lens( 放大镜 ) in his pocket.
“We have at least an hour before us,” he remarked,
“for they can hardly take any steps until the good pawnbroker( 当铺老板 ) is safely in bed.
Then they will not lose a minute,
for the sooner they do their work the more time they will have for their escape.
We are now, Doctor—as no doubt you have guessed—in the cellar of the City branch of one of the largest London banks.
Mr( 先生 ). Merryweather is the chairman,
and he will explain to you that there are reasons why the more daring criminals of London should take a considerable interest in this cellar at present.”
“It is our French gold,” whispered the director.
“We have had several warnings that an attempt might be made upon it.”
“Your French gold?”
“Yes. Some months ago we needed more reserves, and borrowed for that purpose 30,000 gold Napoleon coins from the Bank of France.
It has become known that we have never unpacked the money, and that it is still lying in our cellar.
The crate( 大木箱 ) upon which I sit contains 2,000 coins.
Our gold reserves are much larger at present than the amount usually kept in a single branch office,
and the directors have had some concerns on the subject.”
“Which were very well justified,” observed Holmes.
“And now it is time that we made our plans.
I expect that we will need to act within the next hour.
In the meantime, Mr( 先生 ). Merryweather, we must put the screen over that dark lantern.”
“And sit in the dark?”
“I am afraid so.
I have a pack of cards in my pocket, and I thought that perhaps you might have your card game after all.
But I see that the enemy’s preparations have gone so far that we cannot risk the presence of a light.
And, first of all, we must choose our positions.
These are daring men, and though we shall take them at a disadvantage, they may do us some harm unless we are careful.
I shall stand behind this crate( 大木箱 ), and you hide yourselves behind those.
Then, when I flash a light( 照亮 ) upon them, close in swiftly.
If they fire, Watson, then shoot them down.”
I placed my gun, ready to fire, upon the top of the wooden case behind which I had hidden myself.
Holmes closed the slide across the front of his lantern and left us in total darkness.
The smell of hot metal remained to assure( 使确信 ) us that the light was still there, ready to shine out at any moment.
To me, with my nerves( 神经 ) in such a state of expectancy,
there was something depressing( 令人抑郁的 ) about the sudden darkness, and in the cold, smelly air of the vault( 金库 ).
“They have only one way of escape,” whispered Holmes.
“That is back through the house into Saxe-Coburg Square.
I hope that you have done what I asked you, Jones?”
“l have an inspector and two officers waiting at the front door.”
“Then we have stopped all the escape routes( 路线 ). And now we must be silent and wait.”

article_info.previous: Holmes和Dr. Waston查看了Mr. Wilson当铺前的街道情况，设法见了助手Vincent Spaulding一面.Holmes推测红发会事件背后隐藏着大阴谋，他和Dr. Waston约定晚上采取行动阻止这一犯罪活动。
article_info.share_words: To me, with my nerves in such a state of expectancy, there was something depressing about the sudden darkness, and in the cold, smelly air of the vault.

options.en: Only Dr. Watson and the official police detective Peter Jones.

options.cn: Dr. Waston，警探Peter Jones和银行董事Mr. Merryweather。
options.en: Dr. Watson, the official police detective Peter Jones, and the bank director Mr. Merryweather.

analysis: 文中提到：“On entering his room I found Holmes in lively conversation with two men, one of whom I recognized as Peter Jones, the official police detective, while the other was a long, thin, sad-faced man, with a shiny hat and a long, very respectable coat.”且后文提到：“This fellow Merryweather is a bank director, and personally concerned in the matter.”所以选C。

question.cn: 他们四人会合之后去了哪里？
question.en: Where did the four people go after they got together?

options.en: They went to Mr. Wilson’s house.

options.cn: 他们去了伦敦一家大银行的市内分行的大厅。
options.en: They went to the lobby of the City branch of one of the largest London banks.

options.cn: 他们去了伦敦一家大银行的市内分行的地下室。
options.en: They went to the cellar of the City branch of one of the largest London banks.

analysis: 文中提到：“We are now, Doctor—as no doubt you have guessed—in the cellar of the City branch of one of the largest London banks.”所以选C。

question.cn: Mr. Merryweather用手杖捣地砖的时候为什么感到惊讶？
question.en: Why was Mr. Merryweather surprised when he stroke his stick upon the floor?

options.en: Because there was someone asking for help.

analysis: 文中提到：“‘Why, dear me, it sounds quite hollow!’ he remarked, looking up in surprise.”所以选C。

question.cn: 罪犯们为什么会对银行的这间地下室感兴趣？
question.en: Why were the criminals interested in the cellar of the bank?

options.cn: 因为他们想得到地下室里存放的纸币。
options.en: Because they wanted the banknotes stored in the cellar.

options.cn: 因为他们想得到地下室里存放的法国黄金。
options.en: Because they wanted the French gold stored in the cellar.

options.cn: 因为他们想得到地下室里存放的珠宝。
options.en: Because they wanted the jewelry stored in the cellar.

analysis: 文中银行董事Mr. Merryweather的回答是：“It is our French gold. . . It has become known that we have never unpacked the money, and that it is still lying in our cellar.”所以选B。

question.cn: 在等待罪犯们到来的过程中，这四个人做了什么？
question.en: What did the four people do while waiting for the criminals?

options.cn: 他们坐在黑暗中，其他什么都没做。
options.en: They sat in the dark and did nothing more.

options.cn: 他们一直在聊天，直到罪犯们到来。
options.en: They chatted with each other until the criminals came.

options.cn: 他们一直在打牌，直到罪犯们到来。
options.en: They played cards until the criminals came.

analysis: 文中提到：“‘And sit in the dark?’ ‘I am afraid so.’ ‘I have a pack of cards in my pocket, and I thought that perhaps you might have your card game after all. But I see that the enemy’s preparations have gone so far that we cannot risk the presence of a light.’”后面还提到：“And now we must be silent and wait.”所以选A。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第50天
